BC-BKN-SUNS-NEWCOMERS-AZR 
SUNS DON'T MIND BEING UNKNOWN COMMODITY 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By NORM FRAUENHEIM  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   PHOENIX - The Suns find themselves in an unusual spot. Almost
unprecedented.

   They've always been a team with a hook, an identity. The team
that lost the coin flip for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in the late 1960s
became basketball's prettiest team in the 1980s. They swaggered
through the early 1990s with the raucous and unrepentant Charles
Barkley pushing them to the edge.

   But as they escape the NBA lockout and approach the millennium,
the Suns are caught in anonymity. Call them Team Mystery. Who are
these guys?

   With Jason Kidd, Tom Gugliotta and Danny Manning, the Suns have
their share of proven, well-known players. But the eventual mix has
been hard to evaluate for even the Suns.

   ``I don't have a much better idea than anybody else at this
point,'' said Suns Coach Danny Ainge, whose work in progress
started amid the chaos of an abbreviated training camp and a
frenetic free-agent shuffle that started with the loss of Antonio
McDyess to Denver and continued with the acquisition of Gugliotta.

   Despite all the early uncertainty, Ainge remains upbeat about
chances that the Suns will strike the right mix and challenge at
the end of a 50-game season. The only sure bet is that they won't
repeat last season's 56 wins.

   Whatever success they have won't come easily. With Michael
Jordan's retirement and the disbanding of the Chicago dynasty, the
NBA's balance of power has shifted West.

   In all the preseason handicapping, the Suns are picked to finish
no better than fifth. In other words, they are an afterthought. Go
ahead, ask a coach _ almost any coach _ for his preseason analysis.
Inevitably, the Suns are almost forgotten.

   In conference calls with league coaches this week, Del Harris of
the Los Angeles Lakers, one of the favorites, talked about the Utah
Jazz, San Antonio Spurs, Houston, Rockets and Seattle SuperSonics
before he hastily included the Suns as a possibility toward the end
of his remarks. Harris wanted to be careful not to exclude the
Suns, but it was evident that he didn't know what to make of them.

   There's a built-in advantage amid the anonymity. The Suns have a
chance to surprise.

   ``He's right, the West is strong,'' Kidd said of Harris'
preseason analysis. ``You've got a lot of teams that are talented,
with the Lakers, Houston, Utah, San Antonio and Seattle. Hopefully,
we can just lay in the weeds. Those teams are the most dangerous.
Those teams have all the pressure.

   ``Nobody's talking about us, and that's the way to start a
season. You want them ``all'' to be talking about you at the end.''

   The lack of preseason buzz surrounding the Suns is rooted in two
areas: suspect depth and suspect defense.

   Of the two, the first appears to be the most critical. Fears of
season-ending injuries are unavoidable in the Suns' thinking.

   Guard Rex Chapman, a dependable shooter and unyielding
competitor, might not play in tonight's opener against the Clippers
in Los Angeles because of a nagging problems with his right
hamstring. Over a compressed schedule with sometimes four games a
week, there is concern about whether Chapman can last. The worry
explains this week's acquisition of swingman Chris Morris.

   Morris has some of the same versatility as guard-forward George
McCloud, who is a possible starter in his second season on the
Phoenix roster. Morris could be a redundant addition. But in a
compressed season, Ainge might need as many parts as possible, no
matter how redundant.

   Furthermore, there are questions about the backups at nearly
every position. Kidd's backup, Gerald Brown, the Terry Porter
look-alike from Carl Hayden High School, showed poise and ability
in two preseason victories over Dallas. But he has yet to play in a
regular season game.

   The same can be said of forward Pat Garrity, a first-round draft
pick, and Toby Bailey, a second-round pick. Against Dallas, both
played well enough to suggest that maybe the Suns have found some
keepers. Bailey looks to be agile and tough. In two exhibitions
against Dallas, Garrity averaged 15.5 points on 50 percent
shooting. But, again, neither has appeared in a regular season
game.

   The other question, defense, was highlighted against Dallas, a
league lightweight last year. The Mavericks averaged 109.5 points
in the two exhibition games. The current Mavericks are a collection
of ex-Suns who gave up 116.5 points to the current Suns. Can any of
these Suns play defense?

   In time, Ainge thinks so. The physical Kidd already is
acknowledged as one of the league's best backcourt defenders. With
the acquisition of 7-foot-2 center Luc Longley from Chicago, the
Suns can start one of the biggest front lines in their history with
6-10 Gugliotta at one forward and 6-10 Clifford Robinson at the
other.

   They also appear to be more equipped to endure the slower, more
physical playoffs.

   One thing appears unchanged. The Suns always have been a team
built to score. The good news is that the offense looks as potent
as ever, especially with a front line that includes some of the
best passers among the league's big men. With Kidd as the
playmaker, the Suns could be dangerous to play and entertaining to
watch.

   ``It's going to be a fun team,'' said Gugliotta, who figures to
benefit alongside Kidd, whose pass-first, shoot-second philosophy
is the flip side to Minnesota's Stephon Marbury. ``We move the ball
real well. The chemistry should be real good.''

   But until the mixture can be uncapped and tested, the Suns
remain an unknown commodity.
